metadata.title: High-Rate Assembly of Nanomaterials on Insulating Surfaces Using Electro-Fluidic Directed Assembly

sections.text:
KEYWORDS: directed assembly, electrophoresis, fluidic assembly, concentration gradient, nanoparticles, nanotubes
Directed assembly of nanomaterials such as nano-particles, carbon nanotubes, nanowires, etc. has been avast area of study over the last two decades. Various directed assembly techniques have been developed where nanomaterials are assembled into one-, two-, and threedimensional nanostructures onto surfaces by utilizing externally applied electric,1,2 magnetic,3 and convective forces4 and fluidic assembly.5 Assembly using nanomaterials has been used to make functional nanostructures enabling superior device performance and miniaturization in sensors, electronics, optics, energy, and biotechnology applications.2,5−8 For example, dielectrophoretic assembly of nanowires and nanotubes has been conducted to make functional nanostructures and devices.9,10 There are many barriers, however, such as scalability, throughput, yield, repeatability, and integration of different components that have not been fully addressed for commercialization. A few of these barriers have been addressed through using template-guided assembly to assemble nanomaterials to achieve desired nanoscale 2D or 3D architectures.11,12 For example, a fluidic assembly process where capillary force is the dominant assembly mechanism is amenable to a variety of nanomaterials.13,14 However, these processes are diffusion-limited and take several
hours to assemble over a few inches. A convective directed assembly process that utilizes meniscus and evaporation enables precision assembly with single-particle resolution4 takes several hours to assemble over a few millimeters. Although these processes have shown precision assembly with high resolution at the micro and nanoscale, each has serious scalability and throughput shortcomings that must be addressed. Electric-fieldbased directed assembly is among the most commonly used techniques since it provides a fast and scalable way of assembling a wide range of nanomaterials.12,15−17 The electrophoretic force on the particle is applied via an electric field generated using conductive electrodes/surfaces. However, assembly on conductive surfaces is not always feasible, especially for applications where the nanomaterials need to be assembled on an insulated surface such as transistors, sensors, and many other electronic devices. In these cases, typically, nanomaterials are first assembled on a conductive substrate and then transferred onto

an insulating surface.18 This process can increase the time and the complexity involved in making such devices. To assemble nanomaterials on insulating surfaces, typically, fluidic assembly techniques11,19−22 are used. In these techniques, nanomaterials are driven to the surface using fluidic forces arise from the capillary, liquid evaporation, and diffusion. Despite their great capabilities, most of these techniques can be slow for large area assembly and integration of nanomaterials. Therefore, there is a need for a versatile assembly technique that is scalable, highrate and allows the assembly of various types of nanomaterials on insulating surfaces such as polymers, oxide films, and others. This could potentially enable various practical device applications including flexible sensors23 and electronics.24
In this paper, we have developed a high-rate directed assembly technique, so-called electro-fluidic directed assembly, which uses a combination of electric field and capillary action at the air− liquid interface to enable assembly of nanomaterials on insulating surfaces. The mechanism of electro-fluidic assembly relies on the application of electrophoresis through an insulating surface combined with a typical fluidic assembly, which yields an assembly process that is 2 orders of magnitude faster compared to fluidic assembly. This approach eliminates the fluidic assembly’s diffusion-limited process by bringing the nanoelements from the bulk solution to the assembly region near the patterned substrate and, consequently, increasing the concentration near the substrate. We demonstrated that the assembly process is largely governed by the applied potential, pH of the suspension, pulling speed of the substrate, and the insulating material thickness. Understanding of assembly mechanism led to the controlled assembly of various types of nanoparticles such as copper, SiO2, CdSe, and single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) on polymers and oxides at high rates. To demonstrate the use of the developed electro-fluidic assembly technique in nanoscale device applications, we fabricated a SWCNT-based NO2 gas sensor by directly assembling suspended SWCNTs on SiO2 substrate. The results showed that the developed sensor can detect the change in NO2 concentration from 1 to 5 ppm in air (at 25 °C), showing a promise for highly sensitive sensor applications. In addition, we show the capability of the developed assembly technique in assembling nanomaterials on flexible substrates for potential use in flexible electronics and sensors.

sections.heading: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Substrate Preparation for Electro-Fluidic Assembly. Figure 1a shows the schematic of the patterned substrate prepared for electro-fluidic assembly and the insulating and conductive layers on the substrate. A thin conducting layer is needed underneath the insulating surface to apply an electric field during assembly, as shown in Figure 1b. A wide variety of insulating films (organic and inorganic) can be utilized for the electro-fluidic assembly. The thickness of the insulating layer could be up to 10 μm or larger depending on the dielectric contact of the insulating substrate. An e-beam resist, poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), is applied onto the insulating layer and lithographically patterned using e-beam, as shown in Figure 1a. The patterned substrate and a counter electrode (a gold film on Si wafer) are then submerged (separated by 5 mm) into a suspension containing nanoelements (Figure 1b). The patterned substrate is then pulled from the suspension at a controlled pulling speed. The electric field is continuously applied, while the substrate is being pulled out from the suspension to provide an additional force to help prevent the detachment of the assembled nanoelements.16 All experiments were conducted in a controlled environment with 30% humidity and at 27 °C temperature. To fully assess the capability or the technique, a baseline was established for fluidic assembly in the absence of an applied electric field. The effect of pulling speed was also considered in establishing the baseline because of its effect on the assembly efficiency (AE). Since the fluidic assembly process depends on the diffusion of the particles toward the substrate, the effect of the pulling speed of the substrate becomes very influential.20 Figure 2 shows that the AE is dependent on the pulling speed. The AE results were quantified using imaging software to analyze the contrast differences in SEM images, where the dark regions indicate particle assembly and the white regions indicate no assembly (see Supporting Information, Figure S1). For example, higher assembly efficiencies are obtained at 0.05 mm/min pulling speed, which yields an AE ∼ 95%. The AE decreases as the pulling speed is increased due to the insufficient nanoparticle concentration in the vicinity of the patterned substrate. The assembly time is calculated by measuring the meniscus travel time over the patterned substrate. For example, a 10 mm × 10 mm substrate at 0.05 mm/min pulling speed will have a total assembly process of 120 min. This time is sufficient for the
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7680
suspended nanoparticles to migrate from the bulk solution to the assembly region and to completely fill the patterns. However, at a pulling speed of 3 mm min−1, the total assembly time will be <3 min, and only few particles that are in the vicinity of the patterned surface are assembled resulting in an AE of <3%. Therefore, since one of the attributes of the developed process is high rate, the 3 mm/min pulling speed was chosen as the baseline speed for the electro-fluidic assembly experiments to contrast the technique with fluidic assembly. After selecting an appropriate baseline pulling speed, the study of the electro-fluidic assembly requires investigating several parameters that govern this assembly process such as applied voltage, the charge on the particles, and the thickness of the insulating layer. Control of Electro-Fluidic Assembly. The magnitude of the electrophoretic force on a particle is equal to the product of the charge q of the particle and the electric field E generated between the substrate and the electrodes. Therefore, AE is a function of both parameters. For a spherical nanoparticle of radius R, the charge on a nanoparticle can be calculated using π ε κ ζ= +q R R4 (1 ) , where ε is the dielectric constant of the solution, ζ is the nanoparticle zeta potential which is a function of the pH and ionic strength of the solution, and κ is the Debye− Huckel parameter which is the inverse Debye length.25 The electric field E also changes as a function of the applied voltage. For two parallel plates with bare surfaces, E can be calculated by dividing the voltage difference between the plates by their separation distance. However, in our substrate configuration, E is non-uniform near the trenches due to the insulating patterned geometries (shown in Figure 5).
We first investigated the effect of the applied voltage on the electro-fluidic assembly process. In these experiments, we kept the pulling speed, the charge on the particles, and the thickness of the insulating layer constant and investigated the effect of voltage between 2 and 5 V (see Supporting Information, page 3). The thickness of the insulating film was fixed at 150 nm, and the pH of the suspension was maintained at 10.9 where the zeta potential of the particles was measured as −60 ± 2.1 mV. The objective is to significantly increase the AE at the baseline pulling speed (3mm/ min) by increasing the electrophoretic force on the particles. Figure 3a shows SEM images and corresponding assembly efficiencies at different voltages. The figures exhibit great enhancement of the assembly of nanoparticles at higher applied electric fields. When the voltage is <3 V, it yielded a lower AE (<40%). However, at 3 V, the AE increased to about 70%, and at 3.4, the electrophoretic force on the particles was greatly increased due to the larger electric field resulting in full assembly (AE of 100%). Considering such a high AE was only observed at a pulling speed that is 60 times slower (0.05 mm/min) using fluidic assembly (Figure 2a), this shows that the introduction of voltage to the fluidic assembly process significantly increased the speed of the assembly process by 60 times. We have also investigated the effect of particle charge on the electro-fluidic assembly process. As explained earlier, the charge on the particles is a function of zeta potential ζ and Debye length κ of the particles. The zeta potential also depends on the particle solution properties such as pH and ionic strength.19 The charge of the polystyrene latex (PSL) particles used in our experiments showed a strong dependence on the pH of the suspension. The dynamic light scattering analysis showed that the zeta potential of the 50 nm PSL particles is −38 mV at pH 10 and −63 mV at pH 11.1, showing that the charge on the PSL particles is much higher at high basic pH, which will increase the electrophoretic force on the particles (see Table S1 for the particle charge calculations). To investigate the effect of the particle charge by controlling the pH on the assembly, we measured the AE for suspensions with pH between 10 and 11.1 while keeping the other parameters (pulling speed, the thickness of the insulating film and voltage) constant. We used the same baseline pulling speed (3 mm/min) and insulating layer thickness (150 nm) as in previous experiments. Figure 3c shows the SEM images and corresponding assembly efficiencies at different pH values. At pH 10 and 10.7, the zeta potentials of the particles were measured to be−41 mV and −57 mV, respectively, and the charges on the particles were calculated as 2.82 × 10−17 C and 1.56 × 10−16 C, respectively. The increase in the particle charge resulted in an increase in the AE from 40% to 60%.When the pHwas increased to 11.1, the charge on the particles became 2.38 × 10−16 C and the AE increased to 95%. These experiments suggest that the electro-fluidic assembly process can also be controlled by controlling the charge on the particles. The pH of the suspension can be adjusted to obtain high particle charge, which leads to an increased electrophoretic force that greatly enhances the efficiency of the fluidic assembly process. The control of voltage and the pH leads to a uniform high efficiency nanoparticle assembly over the entire trench area. The uniformity of the assembly was shown using AFM imaging in Figure 3d. For the 100% AE with full assembly in the trenches, the variation in the uniformity of the nanoparticle thickness through the entire trench array was calculated to be within 5%. Figure 4 displays the AE as a function of applied voltage and pH for three different pulling speeds. The contour plots provide a well-characterized AE regions for different pH−voltage−pulling
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7681
speed combinations. At a slower pulling speed of about 1 mm min−1, high AE is obtained even at intermediate levels of pH and voltage since the assembly at a lower speed would be largely dominated by fluidic assembly rather than electro-fluidic
assembly. When we further increase either the pH or voltage at low speeds, we observed an excessive number of particles that are deposited all over the surface and not just in the patterned structures (see Figure S3). In contrast, as the pulling speed is
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7682
increased, the high assembly region (AE > 70%) moved toward the high pH-voltage region. We were able to achieve 100% AE at a pulling speed of 5 mm/min by applying 3.6 V at pH 11. These results showed that the speed of the electro-fluidic assembly is 100 times faster while obtaining full assembly as compared to fluidic assembly. Obtaining a 100% AE at higher pulling speed (>5 mm/min) required the application of higher voltages (∼5 V). However, excess potential causes water electrolysis and bubble formation in the solution that affects the assembly (see Figure S3c). To understand the effect of insulating film thickness on the electro-fluidic assembly, we conducted experiments on patterned insulated substrates having two different SiO2 film thicknesses (50 nm and 1 μm). The same assembly conditions (3 V, pH 11.1, and 3 mm/min) that provided full assembly for 150 nm thick SiO2 film were applied to both samples. The 50 nm thin insulator substrate showed over assembly (particle deposition on the PMMA) at the same conditions where the 1 μm thick insulator showed that fewer particles were assembled as shown in Figure 5a. To investigate this further, a 3D computational fluid dynamics simulation (see Figure S4) was utilized to model the electric field over the insulated surface. Since the insulating layer (dielectric) is between the two conductive layers (a substrate and a counter electrode), an electric field is generated within the dielectric when a voltage is applied (Figure 5b). In the presence of the insulating surface, the highest electric field is observed at the oxide−PMMA interface due to the fringing field effect.26 The simulation results also show that the electric field strength drastically changes with the thickness of the insulating material (Figure 5c). The simulations show that, for an applied voltage of 3 V, the 50 nm thick SiO2 exhibited an electric field magnitude of 140 kV/m, whereas it decreased to 20 kV/m for the 1 μm thick SiO2. Therefore, a very high electrophoretic force was exerted on the particles when 50 nm thick SiO2 film is used, which resulted in over deposition. On the other hand, the electrophoretic force was very low for the 1 μm thick SiO2 film, and only a few particles were assembled in the trenches. The particle assembly would be
enhanced by adjusting the applied voltage to provide the required electrophoretic force for a proper assembly for each film thickness. For instance, in the case of 50 nm SiO2 substrate, lowering the applied voltage from 3 to 2.5 V resulted in full assembly in the trenches without over deposition (Figure 5a). Similarly, for the one 1 μm thick SiO2, when the voltage is increased from 3 to 3.3 V, a full assembly of particles is obtained as shown in Figure 5a. This indicates that the presented electrofluidic assembly technique can be used to assemble nanoparticles on insulating materials with various thicknesses ranging from 50 nm up to microns by adjusting the process parameters to provide a sufficient electrophoretic force for full assembly. Although it is expected that electrowetting plays a role in the electrofluidic assembly process, however, without the applied electric field, the particle concentration near patterned substrates will be too low to account for the significant improvement in assembly. Therefore, electrowetting by itself does not play a dominant role in the observed significant improvement in assembly.
The Effect of Applied Electric Field on Nanoparticle Concentration near Insulating Substrates. The nanoparticle concentration distribution near the insulating substrate is investigated by evaluating the florescent particle intensity near the surface of the insulated substrate under the influence of electric field. The experimental results and procedure are explained in the Supporting Information including the concentration baseline before applying the electric field and the calibration curve used for measuring the particle concentration as a function of the applied electric field. The experiment was conducted using a tube that initially has a uniform concentration of particles. The tube has an electrode (conductive electrode and a conductive substrate coated with an insulating layer) at each end of the tube with a 5 mm separation distance. Particle concentration enhancement was observed by comparing intensity changes under fluorescent microscope as a function of electric field. Red fluorescent PSL particle with a 1 wt % concentration was used. The concentration distribution under the applied electric field was measured for a specific assembly
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7683
condition at 3.4 V and pH 10.9, which, from previous measurements, gives full assembly at 3 mm/min that corresponds to an assembly time of 100 s. Figure 6 (top)
shows the surface concentration enhancement for an applied voltage of 3.4 V and pH of 10.9 using 1 wt % bulk solution concentration. Figure 6 (bottom) shows the surface concentration as a function of time at the same applied voltage and pH. The figure demonstrates the effect of applied electric filed on the enhancement of nanoparticles concentration near the patterned substrate. Capabilities of the Electro-Fluidic Assembly. For practical applications, the developed assembly technique should assemble a variety of nanomaterials into geometries with different widths, depths, and orientations. Figure 7a shows the successful assembly of 50 nm PSL nanoparticles into 100 nm, 200 nm, 500 nm, and 1 μm wide and 150 nm deep trenches (Figure 7a). For this case, full assembly (AE of 100%) for all considered widths was observed at 3.4 V, pH 10.9, and 3 mm/ min pulling speed (oxide thickness is 150 nm). Similarly, the same particles were effectively assembled into the 300 nm wide trenches using four different trench depths (50, 150, 300, and 800 nm). To obtain full particle coverage inside the trenches with different depths, the pulling speed needs to be adjusted. For example, when 3.4 V, pH 10.9, and 3 mm/min pulling speed was used, the 50 nm thick PMMA resulted in a monolayer particle assembly (Figure 7b). The same parameters yielded multilayer assemblies for the 150 and 300 nm deep trenches and filled the entire trench. However, when using a slightly slower pulling speeds (2 mm/min), full assembly is obtained for the entire 800 nm deep trench. The use of slower speed increased the assembly time allowing more particles to migrate toward the patterns. These experiments suggest that the thickness of the nanoparticle assembly can be controlled for the assembly of structures with
different depths by controlling the pulling speed. AFM images taken after the removal of PMMA shows that the nanoparticle assembly is uniform even for the high aspect ratio structures (Figure 7b). In addition, the orientation of the patterns can be crucial for applications that require fabrication of complex patterns or geometries. In most fluidic-based assemblies, the flow direction is set parallel to the patterns direction,19 making them unsuitable for creating complex patterns at high rates. To show the capability of the electro-fluidic assembly, we fabricated inclined and crossbar patterns and investigated the nanoparticle assembly into these geometries as a function of the pulling direction (Figure 7c). The patterns were fabricated such that the angles between the pulling direction and patterns are 45° for the inclined geometries and 0° and 90° for the crossbar geometries. The pulling speed and pH of the suspension were set to 3 mm/ min and 10.9, respectively, and the voltage was varied. At 2.8 V, the particles only assembled at the top edge of the inclined and crossbar geometries. This was similar to the fluidic assembly results in Figure 2 indicating that the assembly was mainly driven by capillary force. However, at 3 V, more particles were assembled in the features with AE ∼ 50%. At this voltage, significant assembly was also observed at the side edges of the crossbar structures. This indicates that electrophoretic force begins to play a role in the electro-fluidic assembly process.When the voltage was increased to 3.3 V, full assembly was obtained in the inclined and crossbar geometries. These results indicate that electro-fluidic assembly can be used to fabricate complex structures regardless of fluid (or pulling) direction at high rates. Figure 8 shows the capability of the developed assembly process in terms of assembling a wide range of nanomaterials (metallic, semiconductors, and insulators). By controlling the governing parameters such as voltage, charge, and pulling speed, we successfully assembled fluorescent silica, CdSe quantum dots, and copper nanoparticles on a silicon oxide surface (Figure 8a− c). Controlled assembly of quantum dots could enable the fabrication nanostructures at ambient temperature and pressure to be used in photovoltaics27,28 and memory devices.29 Also, assembly of metallic nanoparticles such as copper can be used to make interconnects in electronics.30We also assembled SWCNT into nanoscale channels (Figure 8d). The assembly of CNTs is typically more challenging than the nanoparticles due to their high aspect ratio. The alignment of CNTs is also important for electronic applications since it has an effect on their electronic properties.31,32 Highly aligned CNTs in nanoscale channels show more semiconducting behavior rather than metallic.23 As shown in Figure 8d, electro-fluidic assembly enabled the assembly and alignment of CNTs in 500 nm channels on a 150 nm thick oxide film.
NO2 Gas Sensor Enabled by Electro-Fluidic Assembly. To demonstrate the electro-fluidic assembly capability for making devices, we fabricated a miniaturized CNT-based NO2 gas sensor. The electrical properties of CNTs are very sensitive to exposure to chemical or biomolecules,33,34 making them ideal materials for gas sensing applications.35 In addition, the high surface-to-volume ratio of the CNT makes it possible to detect molecules at low concentrations. Nitrogen dioxide is a byproduct of combustion and other industrial applications. It is acutely toxic and adversely affects the respiratory organs, even at low ppm level concentrations.36 Hence the detection of nitrogen dioxide in lower concentration is necessary for the determination of the concentration of NO2 in air. Using electro-fluidic assembly, we have fabricated a chemi-resistive NO2 sensor by assembling
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7684
CNTs on a SiO2 (insulating layer) in a nanoscale channel. The pulling speed was 3 mm/min, and the voltage was 3 V. The width and the length of the CNT channel were 300 nm and 10 μm, respectively, and the thickness of the CNTs was 150 nm. The sensor was tested in a sealed glass chamber, and the measurements were conducted at a constant temperature with controlled humidity (Figure 9a). Figure 9a shows the fabricated device after the chip is mounted on a chip carrier and wirebonded. The gas sensor was tested by measuring the change in the electrical resistance of the assembled CNTs when exposed to NO2. The current−voltage (I−V) characteristic of the sensor was measured using a semiconductor parameter analyzer (Agilent). The resistance for the sensor channel was approximately 8 kΩ at room temperature (see Figure S7). When exposed to NO2 gas, the conductivity of the p-type CNTs increases since nitrogen dioxide is an electron-donating group. Figure 9b shows the sensitivity of the assembled CNTs when the concentration was varied between 1 ppm to 5 ppm in air at 25 °C. Figure 9c shows the change in the resistance of the CNT channel, where R is the resistance value of the sensor after the injection of NO2, and R0 is the initial resistance value of the channel. The results show that the change in the resistance is linearly proportional to the NO2 concentration added. Linear extrapolations of the sensitivity data indicated that the CNT channel is capable of detecting NO2 down to 1 ppm. Considering the low detection limit, the very small sensing area (300 nm × 10 μm) and the speed of the assembly (<1 min), the developed process potentially enables the fabrication of miniaturized and highly sensitive gas sensor platforms at a high rate. The sensor presented here uses bare CNTs (without functional groups), therefore, it can be used for
nonspecific sensing applications. However, the CNT surface can also be functionalized with specific molecules to make a specific sensor for targeted gases.35
Applications on Flexible Substrates. The presented assembly technique can also be used to assemble structures on flexible or stretchable substrates for flexible device applications. Flexible electronics open the door tomany applications including foldaway displays,37 lightweight solar cells,38 and wearable sensors.23 Incorporation of nanomaterials onto flexible substrates also enhances the functionality of the produced devices.18 Many methods involve assembly of nanomaterials on a template followed by a transfer onto a flexible substrate,39 which is a twostep process. This electro-fluidic approach enables the directed assembly of nanomaterials onto flexible substrates. In addition, the fact that the entire process is performed at ambient temperature and pressure makes it compatible with wide range of polymers used in flexible electronics. To demonstrate the potential of using the process on flexible substrates, we assembled silica nanoparticles onto a patterned polyimide (PI) substrate (see Supporting Information for PI substrate fabrication). The PI film was deposited onto a doped Si wafer that acts as a conductive layer for the electro-fluidic assembly. Figure 10a shows the assembly of 50 nm silica particles into 300 nm wide trenches and 50 μm long trenches. For the 10 μm thick PI, the magnitude of the electric field near the channels was significantly lower than the electric fields near the SiO2 surfaces shown in Figure 5. However, sufficient electric field still exists near the substrate to exert enough electrophoretic force on the particles.40 As shown in Figure 10a, all the channels had full particle assembly when the pH of the suspension was maintained
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7685
at 11.1 and 3.4 V was applied while the substrate is pulled at 3 mm/min. Following the assembly, the PI can be easily be peeled off from the substrate to be used for flexible device applications (Figure 10b−d).

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have developed an electro-fluidic directed assembly technique that is capable of assembling a wide range of nanomaterials on insulating rigid or flexible substrates at high rates. The developed process is 2 orders of magnitude faster than conventional fluidic assembly techniques and enables direct assembly of nanomaterials on insulating surfaces without the need for a transfer step. The results show that the electro-fluidic assembly process is governedmainly by the electric field strength, pH of the solution, and the pulling speed of the patterned substrate. The understanding and control of these parameters enabled successful assembly of nanoparticles (metallic, semiconducting and insulating) and CNTs into various patterns down to 100 nm resolution. Using the presented technique, we have fabricated CNT-based gas-sensing device for detecting NO2 concentrations down to 1 ppm. In addition, we have demonstrated high-rate electro-fluidic assembly of nanoparticles on flexible substrates. The presented results show that the presented approach provides a viable pathway for scalable nanomaterial-based fabrication of nanoscale device applications.

sections.heading: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sections.text:
Patterned Substrate Fabrication. A 100 nm gold film is sputtered using MRC 8667 magnetron sputtering tool on a silicon substrate. An oxide layer (50 nm, 150 nm, 300 nm, 500 nm, 1 μm) is then deposited on top of the gold layer by PECVDmethod and using STS PECVD tool. Doped wafers could be directly used instead of deposition a gold film
onto a SI wafer. The wafers are then diced into 10 mm × 10 mm square chips. The oxide on a 1 mm area at the edge of the chip was etched from each chip using buffered oxide etchant (BOE, 1:10) to establish a contact region for applying an electric field. Diced chips were cleaned with Piranha Solution (H2S O4/H2O2, 2:1) and had a contact angle lower than 5°. Chips were baked at 150 °C to eliminate organic contamination. A 150 nm poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) was spun coated on these chips. The PMMA had a contact angle of ∼73° after baking at 115 °C for 90 s. Next, e-beam lithography was conducted using a SUPRA25 FESEM fitted with a RAITH beam blanker and operated by J.C. NABITY pattern generation system (Supra 25, 30 kV, aperture 10 μm, line dose 1.3 nC cm−1). Development was conducted using a mixture of methyl isobutyl ketone and isopropyl alcohol (1:3 by volume).
Nanoelement Suspension Preparation. Fluorescent polystyrene latex (PSL) nanoparticles (d = 51 nm supplied by Thermo Scientific, USA), silica particles (30 nm in diameter purchased from KiskerBiotech, Germany), quantum dots (5 nm purchased from NN Laboratories, USA), copper nanoparticles (80 nm supplied by Meliorum), and single-walled carbon nanotubes (Brewer Science, USA) were used in the assembly experiments. The ultrasonication (Crest ultrasonic tank with 132 kHz frequency) plays an important role for separating particles especially for high-concentration solutions which may contain significant agglomerations. Therefore, bench-type sonication was used to sonicate solutions for 10 min. A pH meter Sension2 (Hach Company) was used to measure the pH of the suspension. The pH meter was calibrated with three different standards (pH 4, 7, and 10) with a calibration slope between −55 mV and −58 mV. NH4OH (Baker Co.) was used to adjust the pH and conductivity of the solution. The zeta potential was measured using a Malvern ZS Nano S analyzer (Malvern Instrument Inc., London, UK).Measurement of the zeta potential of high concentration of nanoparticles was obtained using diluted solution to 0.05% (mass fraction). The measurements were conducted atT = 25 °C. Each experiment was repeated at least five times to calculate the mean value of the measured zeta potential.
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.6b07477 ACS Nano 2017, 11, 7679−7689
7686
Electric Field Simulation. The magnitudes of the electrical potential and electric field counters near the patterns were simulated using a commercial 3D finite-volume modeling software (FLOW-3D).

author: O.D. Velev

author: O.D. Velev
S. Gupta

author: Koh
S. J

references.title: Nanotube Molecular Wires as Chemical Sensors
author: K. Cho
H. Dai

metadata.abstractText: Conductive or semiconducting nanomaterials-based applications such as electronics and sensors often require direct placement of such nanomaterials on insulating surfaces. Most fluidic-based directed assembly techniques on insulating surfaces utilize capillary force and evaporation but are diffusion limited and slow. Electrophoretic-based assembly, on the other hand, is fast but can only be utilized for assembly on a conductive surface. Here, we present a directed assembly technique that enables rapid assembly of nanomaterials on insulating surfaces. The approach leverages and combines fluidic and electrophoretic assembly by applying the electric field through an insulating surface via a conductive film underneath. The approach (called electro-fluidic) yields an assembly process that is 2 orders of magnitude faster compared to fluidic assembly. By understanding the forces on the assembly process, we have demonstrated the controlled assembly of various types of nanomaterials that are conducting, semiconducting, and insulating including nanoparticles and single-walled carbon nanotubes on insulating rigid and flexible substrates. The presented approach shows great promise for making practical devices in miniaturized sensors and flexible electronics.
metadata.creator: Arbortext Advanced Print Publisher 10.0.1465/W Unicode
